titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the CONSOL Energy, Inc. Mine Maps and Records, 1857-2010 AIS.1991.16

did.unittitle: CONSOL Energy, Inc. Mine Maps and Records

physdesc.extent: (305 boxes, 369 tubes, 41 map case drawers, 68 map shelves)

did.abstract: The CONSOL Energy, Inc. Mine Maps and Records contains coal mine maps, related documents and topographical information, as well as surface maps and detailed information on mine accidents. Additionally, there are technical drawings, outside notes on multiple mines, traverse and survey books, information on companies and railroads with which CONSOL conducted business, and a variety of non-print materials including photographs, negatives and aperture cards. Digital reproductions of selected material are available online.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Series XV (Hardback Maps) records may need to be humidified prior to handling. Please contact Archives & Special Collections at least three business days in advance to ensure items can be safely unrolled and handled.
Series XXIII boxes 303 and 304 are an extension of the case file and restricted to use by Archives & Special Collections faculty and staff.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into 22 series:
Series VI. D, E, and F Sheets, 1899-1930
Series XX. Quecreek Mine Accident Investigation, 1900-2004
Series XXI. Photographic and Media Materials, 1930s-1970s
Series XXII. Union Coal and Coke Company Maps, 1899-1968
The collection is organized into 23 series:

list.item: Union Coal and Coke Company Maps, 1899-1968

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: CONSOL Energy Inc. was first introduced and incorporated by an act of the Maryland legislature on March 1860 as Consolidation Coal Company, but was not fully formed until April 19, 1864. Early in CONSOL's history, transportation of coal proved problematic. The coal was originally transferred by wagon, then by flat-bottom riverboats, and later by railroad. The company collaborated with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad when a large amount of stock was acquired by the railroad. Two years later, the offices moved from New York to Baltimore.

The company faced internal trouble in the late 1800s due to the company-employed miners going on strike. The strike continued for weeks, with order finally restored by the Maryland Militia. The early 1900s also saw change in the company, when it expanded outside of Maryland into Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Minnesota and Wisconsin, and began to ship coal internationally to Japan.

In 1906, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad sold its shares to a Baltimore syndicate. This was the first attempt by a railroad to relinquish control of the commodities it transported because of investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which examined the relationships between coal-carrying railroads and the companies having mines on their lines. CONSOL continued to prosper in the early 1900s when it expanded into Kentucky and continued to ship coal all over the world during World War I. The company was able to move its offices back to New York in 1921, and by 1925, the company had become the largest commercial producer of bituminous coal in the United States.

The mergers and reorganizations continued when the company restructured its departments in 1927 to increase efficiency. During the early 1930s and the Depression era, the company again had to reorganize and went into receivership after serious financial trouble befell them, but due to their efforts the company was able to emerge from those years on solid footing.

The year 1934 was the company's seventieth anniversary. They owned 300,000 acres of land containing reserves of 1,800,000,000 tons of coal and operated 22 mines in Maryland, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Kentucky. The years following World War II saw more mergers and the purchasing of other companies. This is also when CONSOL began to develop new breakthroughs in the coal industry.

In 1945, the company merged with Pittsburgh Coal Company and was renamed the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company. One improvement in 1947 was the creation of "Disco," which became a registered trademark of CONSOL. "Disco" was a smokeless solid fuel, and the coal gasification project became a major endeavor of the company. In 1948, the company developed and built a pilot plant for refining tar from a carbonization process.

In 1951, sufficient data became available to prove to CONSOL that it was economical to transport coal by pipeline. In 1956, CONSOL bought the Pocahontas Fuel Company Incorporated, which had reserves and production facilities of low-volatile coal. These fuels were ideal for coking, which was an important ingredient in the manufacture of steel, and a new venture for the coal company. Two years later, the company shortened its name to Consolidation Coal Company.

A major breakthrough for the company occurred in coal pipelining in 1961 with the creation of coal slurry. Coal slurry, a mixture of coal and water, could be pumped for hundreds of miles through a pipeline, distributed by barge, and stored indefinitely in tanks or ponds. This development was hailed as being one of the most important discoveries in fuel transportation and consumption in the past forty years. In 1963, the company contracted with the Office of Coal Research to develop, construct and operate a coal-to-gasoline pilot plant.

The company celebrated 100 years of operation in 1964. Almost 100 billion tons of coal had been mined and CONSOL was still one of the leading producers of coal in the world, with international holdings as well as successful mines located in various states.

In 1966, just two years after the company marked its centennial, Consolidation Coal was acquired by the Continental Oil Company (Conoco). This was part of a general trend whereby U.S. oil companies extended their reach by acquiring coal reserves and large coal producers. In turn, Conoco was acquired by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in 1981. This purchase was motivated by DuPont's desire to obtain better control of chemical feedstocks in an era of high oil prices. Consolidation Coal was not a major factor in the Conoco acquisition and did not really fit into DuPont's strategy, especially after coal and oil prices declined. As a result, it was quickly sold off when DuPont was restructured a decade later.

In 1991, a new holding company, CONSOL Energy Inc., was incorporated as a joint venture of DuPont Energy Company and the German energy conglomerate Rheinisch-Westfalisches Elektrizitatswerk A.G., through its wholly owned subsidiaries Rheinbraun A.G. and Rheinbraun U.S.A. GmbH. Consolidation Coal Company became a wholly-owned subsidiary of CONSOL Energy Inc. DuPont eventually sold most of its half interest, so that by 1998, Rheinbraun affiliates owned 94% of CONSOL Energy stock, while DuPont Energy retained only 6%. CONSOL Energy purchased the entire stock of the Rochester & Pittsburgh Coal Company on September 22, 1998. CONSOL Energy stock began trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "CNX" in 1999, with an initial public offering of more than 20 million shares.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: CONSOL Energy, Inc. Mine Maps and Records, 1857-2010, AIS.1991.16, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains maps, information sheets, technical drawings and other records relating primarily to the southwestern Pennsylvania mining activities of CONSOL Energy, Inc. Additionally, there are property maps, plans of lots and drawings of other surface features, plans of structures related to mines owned and operated by CONSOL Energy and its partnering companies. There are also atlases, maps, technical drawings, information sheets, reports, publications, etc. produced in conjunction with or to be used with the mine maps, and non-print materials including photographs, negatives, slides and aperture cards.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Debora A. Rougeux, Jennifer Roth, Kate Weed, Brigette C. Kamsler, Abigail Miller and Mennie Eldridge from 2005-2011. Materials on West Virginia and Ohio were removed from this collection and added to CONSOL Energy Inc. West Virginia and Eastern Ohio Mine Maps and Records Collection, AIS.2004.22 in March 2012. Information on new materials received related to Union Coal and Coke Company mines in eastern Washington County, Pa., was added in March 2013. Additional processing of linen maps, hardback maps, and processing notes was completed by Amy Brunner in 2019.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: CONSOL Energy, Inc. Mine Maps and Records, 1857-2010, AIS.1991.16, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh
Consolidation Coal Co. Coal Mine Maps Collection, AIS 91:16.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Box 214 was deaccessioned and transferred to the Beall Archives at Frostburg State University. Please contact that institution directly to view those records
The following records have been separated to create the CONSOL Energy Inc. West Virginia and Eastern Ohio Mine Maps and Records Collection, 1880-1994 (AIS.2004.22):

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional material received in 1997, 1998, 2001, 2002, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013. Further accruals are expected.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of CONSOL Energy Inc., beginning in 1991.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of a portion of the photographs in the collection are available electronically at http://historicpittsburgh.org/collection/consol-energy-inc-mine-maps-records. Digital images of surface properties in relation to coal mines from the Monongahela River Consolidated Coal and Coke Company are available in Series XVIII. Records. The I-Tracings (#5000-9999) from this same series were digitized and released online in January 2013 as were the annual reports published by the Pittsburgh Coal Company (1940-1945). CONSOL News and CONSOL Energy News were digitized and released online in December 2013. As part of a multi-year grant project partnering with the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection and the Office of Surface Mining, the hardback maps were digitized and the images are available on the PA Mine Map Atlas here: http://www.paminemaps.psu.edu. Metadata pertaining to each image is available on a DEP website called the Pennsylvania Historic Underground Mine Map Inventory System (PHUMMIS) here: http://www.phummis.pa.gov/phummis/.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: CONSOL Energy Inc. West Virginia and Eastern Ohio Mine Maps and records Collection, 1880-1994, AIS.2004.22, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

did.unittitle: Harmar Mine Maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes maps, information sheets, and technical drawings relating to the Harmar Mine. The Harmar Mine was located in Harmarville, Harmar Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, along Guys Run and the Allegheny River on the Pennsylvania Railroad and Harmar Bridge Canal. The mine was first owned by the Harmar Coal Company (beginning ca. 1915) then by the Consumer Coal Company.

Oakmont Mine Maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes maps, information sheets, and technical drawings relating to the Oakmont Mine, also known as the Barking Mine. It was located in Barking, Plum Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, along a strip of land under the cliffs of Coxcomb hill on the Allegheny Valley Railroad and with barge loading facilities on the Allegheny River. The mine was owned by the Diamond Coal and Coke Company, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

Sewickley Mine Maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes maps and information sheets related to the Sewickley Mine. The Sewickley Mine was a slope mine located in Arona, Hempfield Township, Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania, on the Little Sewickley Creek, half a mile east of Herminie, on the north side of the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks. The mine was owned by Sewickley Gas and Coal Company, Greensburg, Pennsylvania (ca. 1898-1902), then by the Keystone Coal and Coke Company, Greensburg, Pennsylvania (ca. 1903-1920). The Sewickley Mine was merged with Keystone Mine Shaft on June 1, 1920.

scopecontent.p: This series of technical drawings includes plans of air shafts and other structures related to mines. D sheets measure 14" x 20"; E sheets measure 20.25" x 29.5"; and F sheets measure 29" x 42.25".

Survey Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Survey Books document the various mines that were owned and operated by the company for over 100 years. These notebooks were used by surveyors to record both surface and underground data collected while surveying, such as distances, bearings (directional readings), elevation readings, surface property lines, and descriptive information on the location of the survey measurements. These readings enabled the mine engineers to plot and map the progress of mining underground and to locate surface features relative to the underground mine.

In addition, some of the books document the innovations that CONSOL introduced, such as disco, coal slurry, and the use of a coal-to-gasoline plant. Many of the books show day-to-day business activities and include information on coal companies and railroads that did business with CONSOL and accidents that occurred in the mines.

The Survey Books are organized into nine smaller subseries. The books range in date from the late 1800s until the 1990s. The books are arranged alphabetically by mine name and then by book number, the numbering system being the original arrangement from CONSOL.

did.unittitle: Mines, A-Z

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes books labeled alphabetically by mine name. These books constitute the largest subseries in the collection of survey books. Other materials also include strip-mining operations and mines that were leased separate from CONSOL.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of notes and other loose papers that were interweaved between the pages of the transit books. They are organized alphabetically by mine name and are in individual folders. The material includes notes about changes to measurements, correspondence and blueprints of the mines.

Railroads

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes information on the railroads that did business with CONSOL, or that CONSOL had an interest share in stock. Railroads include the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad, the Pittsburgh-Taylortown Railroad, and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Other materials in the subseries detail railroad extensions, measurements and proposed railroad locations.

Accidents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes detailed information on accidents that occurred within the mines. The books list the name of the person injured, how the person had worked in the mines, and descriptions of the events that occurred which led to the accident. Books identify any witnesses and compensation that went to the families of injured persons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes miscellaneous notes having to do with the company and the mines. Materials included are benchmarks that had been met, coal slurry pipelines, an index of the books, haulage amounts, time books and well and gas locations.

Outside Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes information on outside notes from the mines. Mine engineers would use these books to record a multitude of annotations, such as road levels, creek locations and land elevations. The books can include information on mines, railroads, and topography. The books are further organized by issuing Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes books that focus on property surveys around or of the mines. Farmlands, estates and other land tracts are detailed and drawn out with levels and elevations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Traverse logs were used by surveyors and mine engineers to calculate and convert the field survey data collected in the Survey Books to latitude (north-south) and departure (east-west). The calculated information was then in a form such that the data could be added to the surface and underground maps and drawings maintained by the mining company. These books are arranged in alphabetical order by mine name.

Monongahela River Consolidated Coal and Coke Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Monongahela River Consolidated Coal and Coke Company was a railroad and coal transportation company, founded in 1899 in Pittsburgh, Pa. It was formed by merging more than 80 independent coal mines and river transportation businesses, both in Pennsylvania and Kentucky. Initially, it had an agreement with the Pittsburgh Coal Company to ship its coal only by water, and to not compete with it by using rail transport, but the agreement was ended in 1902. It merged with the Pittsburgh Coal Company on December 24, 1915. (From Wikipedia)

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This series was processed during the spring/summer of 2011 and added to the finding aid that October.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series materials are further divided into 13 topical subseries and range in date from 1900 to 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains records and maps gathered together by CONSOL for use by officials investigating the 2002 Quecreek Mine accident. Nine miners working in Quecreek Mine No. 1, thinking they were a safe distance from mine voids, accidentally broke through to the abandoned Saxman Coal & Coke Company's Harrison No. 2 Mine at approximately 8:50 p.m. on July 24, 2002. This resulted in the flooding of the Quecreek Mine, trapping the miners for nearly 78 hours. The series also includes the final reports of investigation filed by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection's Bureau of Deep Mine Safety and the United States Department of Labor's Mine Safety and Health Administration.

did.unittitle: Jennerstown Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, reports, maps, deeds and other records documenting Consolidation Coal Company's Jennerstown Project.

Somerset County Field Survey Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Field Survey Books for mines in Somerset County. These are notebooks used by surveyors to record both surface and underground data collected while surveying, such as distances, bearings (directional readings), elevation readings, surface property lines and descriptive information on the location of the survey measurements. These readings enabled the mine engineers to plot and map the progress of mining underground and to locate surface features relative to the underground mine.

Somerset County Traverse Logs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Traverse Logs for mines and property in Somerset County. These were used by surveyors and mine engineers to calculate and convert the field survey data collected in the Field Survey Books to latitude (north-south) and departure (east-west). The calculated information was then in a form such that the data could be added to the surface and underground maps and drawings maintained by the mining company.

First Aid Teams and First Aid Competitions, ca. 1946-1960s

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Prints depicting first aid demonstrations and competitions sponsored by the coal mining industry, and the mining rescue teams that participated in them. The history of such gatherings dates to October 30, 1911 when the first national mine-safety demonstration was held at Forbes field, in Pittsburgh. The demonstration was planned and managed by engineers of the Bureau with the aid of miners and coal operators of the Pittsburgh district. It embraced exhibits that demonstrated the character of nearly every branch of the Bureau's investigative work in relation to mine accidents, including first-aid and mine-rescue work, coal-dust explosions, and also special coal-dust explosions at the Bureau's experimental mine at Bruceton, Pa. Approximately 15,000 persons attended the demonstration. Thenceforth, first aid contests were annually held in mining towns across the Appalachians and mining country.

Union Coal and Coke Company Maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series primarily includes maps, plans and technical drawings relating to mines and buildings owned and operated by the Union Coal and Coke Company in eastern Washington County, Pa. There are also some maps, plans and technical drawings relating to mines owned and operated by the Ellsworth Collieries Company and other coal operators near those of the Union Coal and Coke Company. Additionally, there are maps of towns and property associated with all of these mines.
